supporting_websites.title: US power use to reach record highs in 2025 and 2026, EIA says
supporting_websites.snippet: The U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA) anticipates U.S. power consumption will hit record highs in 2025 and 2026. Insights from the Short Term Energy Outlook reveal that the surging demand from data centers focused on artificial intelligence and cryptocurrency alongside increased residential, commercial, and transportation electricity needs will push the consumption to 4,179 billion kilowatt hours (kWh) in 2025 and 4,239 billion kWh in 2026, up from 4,082 billion kWh in 2024. The EIA projects increases in power sales across the residential, commercial, and industrial sectors. Additionally, while natural gas and coal's shares of power generation are set to decline, renewable energy is expected to grow, rising from 23% in 2024 to 27% in 2026. Nuclear power's share will remain steady at 19%. Gas sales for residential and commercial use are projected to increase, while industrial and power generation sales will see a decline by 2025.

items.title: Energy contractor Quanta Services trims profit, revenue view on weak demand
items.snippet: Quanta Services has reduced its yearly revenue and profit projections due to decreased demand in its underground utility and infrastructure solutions sector. The company now forecasts annual revenue between $23.5 billion and $23.9 billion, lower than the former estimate of $23.5 billion to $24.1 billion. Adjusted profit per share is anticipated to range from $8.50 to $8.80, slightly down from the previous guideline of $8.32 to $8.87. Declining demand for Quanta's services is attributed to builders' reluctance to initiate new housing projects amid a surplus of new homes in the market. Quarterly revenue was reported at $6.49 billion, falling short of analysts' expectations of $6.57 billion, though adjusted profit per share slightly exceeded predictions, coming in at $2.72 against an estimate of $2.69.

items.title: Puerto Rico power restored to 47% of customers after island-wide blackout
items.snippet: Following a widespread blackout in Puerto Rico, Luma Energy announced that power had been restored to approximately 47% of its 1.5 million customers as of Thursday morning. The company aims to restore electricity to 90% of customers within 48 hours. The island-wide outage comes amid ongoing issues with Puerto Rico's fragile electrical grid, which suffered extensive damage from Hurricane Maria in 2017. Luma Energy, which has managed the territory’s power grid since 2021, attributed the recent blackout to a failure in the protection system and vegetation encroaching on a transmission line between Cambalache and Manatí. In response, the company is investigating the incident and reiterates its commitment to enhancing the safety and reliability of the island's energy infrastructure. Luma is a joint venture between Canadian firm ATCO and U.S.-based Quanta Services.

supporting_websites.title: Puerto Rico's government sues private power company as chronic outages damage appliances
supporting_websites.snippet: The Puerto Rican government has filed a civil lawsuit against Luma Energy, the private company managing the island's power transmission and distribution, over persistent power outages and voltage fluctuations that have damaged consumer appliances. Filed by the consumer affairs department, the lawsuit accuses Luma of negligence and inefficiency, citing the company’s rejection of 1,828 customer claims during a public hearing. Despite being legally shielded from direct lawsuits against individual employees or contractors due to 2021 immunity laws, the government seeks to hold the company itself accountable. Luma responded that it takes the lawsuit seriously and attributes the issues to a deteriorating electrical grid that has suffered from years of neglect and lack of investment, worsened by Hurricane Maria in 2017. The island continues to face widespread outages, most recently including blackouts during New Year’s Eve and Easter Week. The legal action follows mounting public discontent and a promise by the island’s governor to terminate Luma’s contract, acknowledging that the process would be difficult and lengthy. Puerto Rico, home to 3.2 million residents and a 40% poverty rate, continues to struggle with energy instability as its public power authority grapples with $9 billion in debt.

Adjusted profit per share is anticipated to range from $8.50 to $8.80, slightly down from the previous guideline of $8.32 to $8.87. Declining demand for Quanta's services is attributed to builders' reluctance to initiate new housing projects amid a surplus of new homes in the market. Quarterly revenue was reported at $6.49 billion, falling short of analysts' expectations of $6.57 billion, though adjusted profit per share slightly exceeded predictions, coming in at $2.72 against an estimate of $2.69.

items.title: Puerto Rico's government sues private power company as chronic outages damage appliances
items.snippet: The Puerto Rican government has filed a civil lawsuit against Luma Energy, the private company managing the island's power transmission and distribution, over persistent power outages and voltage fluctuations that have damaged consumer appliances. Filed by the consumer affairs department, the lawsuit accuses Luma of negligence and inefficiency, citing the company’s rejection of 1,828 customer claims during a public hearing. Despite being legally shielded from direct lawsuits against individual employees or contractors due to 2021 immunity laws, the government seeks to hold the company itself accountable. Luma responded that it takes the lawsuit seriously and attributes the issues to a deteriorating electrical grid that has suffered from years of neglect and lack of investment, worsened by Hurricane Maria in 2017. The island continues to face widespread outages, most recently including blackouts during New Year’s Eve and Easter Week. The legal action follows mounting public discontent and a promise by the island’s governor to terminate Luma’s contract, acknowledging that the process would be difficult and lengthy. Puerto Rico, home to 3.2 million residents and a 40% poverty rate, continues to struggle with energy instability as its public power authority grapples with $9 billion in debt.

supporting_websites.title: Puerto Rico power restored to 47% of customers after island-wide blackout
supporting_websites.snippet: Following a widespread blackout in Puerto Rico, Luma Energy announced that power had been restored to approximately 47% of its 1.5 million customers as of Thursday morning. The company aims to restore electricity to 90% of customers within 48 hours. The island-wide outage comes amid ongoing issues with Puerto Rico's fragile electrical grid, which suffered extensive damage from Hurricane Maria in 2017. Luma Energy, which has managed the territory’s power grid since 2021, attributed the recent blackout to a failure in the protection system and vegetation encroaching on a transmission line between Cambalache and Manatí. In response, the company is investigating the incident and reiterates its commitment to enhancing the safety and reliability of the island's energy infrastructure. Luma is a joint venture between Canadian firm ATCO and U.S.-based Quanta Services.

entries.title: S&P 500 Nuclear Giant Vistra Sees 21% Revenue Decline, Narrows 2025 Views
entries.snippet:
Vistra (VST), a major nuclear energy company and S&P 500 component, reported disappointing Q3 2025 financial results, with revenue declining 21% year-over-year to $4.97 billion and net income plummeting 65% to $652 million, significantly missing analysts' expectations of $6.115 billion in revenue and $919.6 million in net income. Despite the revenue slide, the company’s adjusted EBITDA from ongoing operations rose 10% to $1.58 billion. Vistra narrowed its 2025 EBITDA forecast to a range of $5.7 billion to $5.9 billion (midpoint unchanged at $5.8 billion) and provided initial 2026 guidance of $6.8 billion to $7.6 billion.

Vistra stock declined 1.6% following the earnings release but is still up 38% in 2025, ranking 61st on the S&P 500. The report also highlighted broader trends in the nuclear sector: other players like Constellation Energy, Talen Energy, BWX Technologies, and small modular reactor (SMR) startups like Oklo and NuScale Power showed mixed financial performances and stock movements. Overall, investor interest remains high due to strong gains by several nuclear and uranium-related companies in 2025, driven by rising demand and expectations of a nuclear energy resurgence.

entries.title: Constellation Energy receives nod from FERC for Calpine acquisition
entries.snippet: Constellation Energy has received regulatory approval from the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) for its planned $16.4 billion acquisition of Calpine Corporation. This approval marks a significant milestone in the progression of the deal, adding to prior consents from the New York Public Service Commission and the Public Utility Commission of Texas. The approvals indicate regulatory confidence in the merger and move the acquisition process closer to completion.

entries.title: Constellation buying Calpine in $26.6 billion deal that would join two huge US power companies
entries.snippet: Constellation is acquiring Calpine, a natural gas and geothermal power provider, in a $26.6 billion deal, creating the leading retail electric supplier in the U.S. The acquisition will serve 2.5 million customers and expand Constellation’s footprint across the continental U.S., including key markets in Texas, California, Delaware, New York, Pennsylvania, and Virginia. The deal includes 50 million Constellation shares, $4.5 billion in cash, and the assumption of $12.7 billion in Calpine debt. The combined company will have nearly 60 gigawatts of capacity from various low- and zero-emission sources. The transaction is expected to add over $2 billion of free cash flow annually, facilitating further investment in zero-emission and low-carbon energy technologies. Pending regulatory approvals, the deal is anticipated to close within a year. Constellation's CEO Joe Dominguez and Calpine's CEO Andrew Novotny emphasized the strategic benefits and commitment to environmentally sustainable energy solutions.

parts:
Here’s a valuation-first read on **Constellation Energy (CEG)**, then the risk profile and what to watch.  
financeturn1finance0

# Snapshot (why it’s special)
- Largest U.S. carbon-free generator, anchored by a top-tier nuclear fleet; increasingly the go-to counterparty for **24/7 clean energy** contracts with hyperscalers (e.g., Microsoft PPA tied to the **Three Mile Island Unit 1** restart, ~**835 MW**, targeted late-decade). citeturn0search2turn0search7turn0search12turn0search17
- Transformational **Calpine** acquisition (gas + geothermal + retail) won **FERC** approval (Jul 23 2025); still awaiting **DOJ** clearance; management guided to closing **Q4 2025**. If completed, CEG becomes a coast-to-coast clean-reliable platform with strong 24/7 product optionality. citeturn0search16turn0news51turn0search6

---

# Valuation (what you’re paying for)
- **Forward P/E ~33×**; **trailing ~36–37×** (varies by feed). This is a premium to typical utilities and many IPPs—market is underwriting durable, above-sector growth from zero-carbon scarcity + data-center demand. citeturn0search18turn0search3
- **EV/EBITDA ~18× (TTM)**; several data providers show **high-teens to mid-20s on forward** depending on Calpine pro-forma and commodity assumptions. That’s rich versus merchant peers, but partly justified by fleet quality, contract mix, and scarcity value. citeturn0search8turn0search13
- Balance-sheet/returns context: CEG’s investor materials emphasize **life-extension + uprates** at existing nukes and high-visibility cash flows; Peach Bottom’s 80-year license shows the playbook (license extensions + capex to sweat assets longer). citeturn0search4turn0search19

**Take:** CEG trades like a secular compounder, not a commodity generator. The multiple assumes (i) 24/7 clean PPAs keep scaling, (ii) nuclear restarts/uprates deliver, and (iii) Calpine closes cleanly and adds optionality without dragging returns.

---

# Risk profile (where it can break)
**1) Deal execution/regulatory:**  
- **Calpine**: despite FERC/PSC approvals, **DOJ** review still pending; any conditions, delay, or failure would dent the “integrated clean + reliable” thesis and could knock the multiple. citeturn0search6

**2) Nuclear operational tail risk:**  
- Forced outages, extended maintenance, or uprate delays can hit earnings and capacity factors; NRC processes for restarts (e.g., TMI-1) are exacting. PPA structures help, but schedule slippage is possible. citeturn0search2turn0search17

**3) Market/price exposure:**  
- Even with hedging/retail, parts of the portfolio remain exposed to **PJM/other market** dynamics (capacity prices, spark spreads). Post-Calpine, CEG will have more gas/retail earnings—good for flexibility, but it modestly raises commodity and retail credit exposure. citeturn0search16

**4) Policy/regulatory drift:**  
- Capacity market rule changes, nuclear policy shifts, or delays in siting/transmission could alter pricing power. (Offset: federal and state policy momentum remains constructive for firm, clean supply.) citeturn0search4

**5) Counterparty/project delivery:**  
- 20-year hyperscaler PPAs are strong credits, but delivery hinges on timely restarts/uprates and grid upgrades near data-center hubs. Slips would push revenue right. citeturn0search7

---

# Why the premium might be deserved
- **Structural demand pull from AI** for 24/7 carbon-free megawatt-hours is real; CEG has first-mover PPAs and the only fleet that can scale that product *now*. The **TMI-1** restart deal is emblematic. citeturn0search7turn0search12
- **Option value**: uprates, life extensions, targeted restarts, and—if/when it closes—**Calpine** broadens the portfolio so CEG can shape around data-center load (clean + firm). citeturn0search4turn0search16

---

# What to monitor (12–18 months)
1) **Calpine closing** (DOJ outcome, terms, timing) and early integration KPIs. citeturn0news51  
2) **24/7 PPA pipeline**—new hyperscaler wins, pricing, duration. citeturn0search2  
3) **Nuclear availability/uprates**—capacity factors, outage days, and NRC milestones for **TMI-1**. citeturn0search17  
4) **Pro-forma leverage/FCF** post-Calpine and capital allocation (u/s on dividend/buybacks vs. fleet capex). Company IR and quarterly packs will spell this out. citeturn0search15

---

## Verdict
- **Quality:** A (scarce carbon-free baseload, credible 24/7 PPA platform)  
- **Execution:** A- (deal + restart/uprates to deliver)  
- **Cyclicality:** Medium (retail/merchant exposure)  
- **Valuation:** **Premium** (mid-30s P/E; high-teens EV/EBITDA)

If you want concentrated, long-duration exposure to the **power-scarcity premium** created by AI/data centers—without taking technology risk—CEG earns a place as a **core hold**. Position size with respect to deal/regulatory timing risk; add on any **Calpine-related wobble** or if nuclear restart milestones clear on schedule.

If you’d like, I can translate this into target sizing (base/overweight/trim levels) and compare it directly with **Vistra** (reliability torque) and **Southern** (regulated nuclear) to balance risk and multiple.

**Evaluating potential holdings**

For long-term holds (10–20 years) with high growth, we have options like Eaton (ETN), Quanta (PWR), and GEV among others. However, some are expensive at current valuations, like PWR and ETN, presenting risks. CEG has premium multiples but faces some operational and regulatory uncertainty. Vistra (VST) offers lower valuations but may be more volatile.

**Evaluating picks for growth vs stability**

GE Vernova (GEV) has growth potential but could be pricey due to its mix of gas power and grid concerns, with risks in wind. HUBB’s high valuation (30x) could be a concern. WMB offers stable, contracted cash flows with moderate growth (mid-single-digit) but may not have the "outsized" growth the user seeks.

**Considering picks for growth**

GE Vernova (GEV) offers potential growth from gas turbines and grid equipment, with risks from wind, but decarbonization trends could improve its trajectory. Eaton (ETN) is strong thanks to rising demand for data center distribution and AI-driven thermal cooling. CEG also shows promise, especially with AI-powered clean energy, but its high valuation may be a concern.

**Assessing the best pick**

The valuations of options like PWR, ETN, GEV, VST, and others are high, and we need to cross-check metrics like P/E and EV/EBITDA. GEV's P/E might be less meaningful, given its recent losses. I'm leaning toward GE Vernova (GEV), as it benefits from both grid equipment and gas power, boosted by the AI-power cycle.

**Selecting the Best Stock**

The user wants a stock with "phenomenal growth" over the next 10-20 years. 

In my opinion, **Eaton (ETN)** stands out as it’s positioned well in AI data centers and grid modernization with high ROIC, though it has premium valuations. **Constellation Energy (CEG)** also offers strong long-term growth, especially given its exposure to 24/7 clean energy and nuclear restarts. 

Given the growth potential and sector alignment, I’d lean toward **Eaton (ETN)**.

**Comparing ETN and CEG**

Between **ETN** and **CEG**, here's the breakdown:

- **ETN** is more industrially diversified and has significant growth in data centers. Boyd Thermal adds crucial capabilities for AI-driven power and thermal complexity, and its broad backlog offers stability. However, valuations are high.  
   
- **CEG** is focused on 24/7 clean energy and nuclear power, with strong long-term PPAs but faces regulatory risks. 

Given your 10–20 year horizon and focus on "phenomenal growth," I'd lean towards **ETN** because of its broader growth opportunities and lower regulatory risk, even if the growth rate isn't as high.

**Considering Alternatives**

CEG’s growth might slow. As alternatives, **Quanta PWR** seems overpriced, which undermines its appeal. **GE Vernova (GEV)** has high potential but is priced very high with early-stage challenges. **BWXT** (nuclear supply) has moderate valuations but isn’t a top pick. **Powell Industries (POWL)**, a small cap, also faces high risk. **Vistra (VST)** could be an attractive "value with torque," but its volatility and evolving sectors complicate things. Given all the factors, a careful choice is needed with strong rationale.

- Boyd Thermal acquisition expands portfolio for liquid cooling.

My pick today is Eaton (ETN). I'll draw on ETN's Q3 press releases for data center orders, their acquisition of Boyd, and provide background through articles like Reuters and MarketWatch. Plus, with a forward P/E of around 27–31, I’ll include relevant citations and present the finance widget.

**Summing up ETN's Advantages**

ETN is well-positioned for both near-term and long-term growth in AI data center electrification and thermal management. It has proven execution, strong margins, and a solid backlog with high-quality balance sheets. Though its valuation is moderate, the low-risk growth potential sets it apart compared to others. 

**Why ETN over the rest?**

- **Versus GEV:** Extremely high P/E.

parts:
**My one pick today: _Constellation Energy (CEG)._**  
It’s the clean‑firm, 24/7 power platform best positioned to monetize AI’s structural pull on electricity—**right now**—with near‑term catalysts (Calpine closing) and medium‑term step‑ups (Three Mile Island Unit‑1 restart) that can compound for a decade+.  
financeturn3finance2

---

## Why CEG over every other candidate—at today’s prices

1) **Own the scarcest product in the AI decade: 24/7 carbon‑free megawatt‑hours.**  
   CEG already signed a 20‑year PPA with Microsoft tied to **restarting Three Mile Island Unit 1 (~835 MW)** by 2028—exactly the kind of long‑dated, premium contract hyperscalers will keep paying for. That deal de‑risks restart economics and validates the playbook (life‑extensions, uprates, targeted restarts). citeturn4search2turn4search6turn4news41

2) **Step‑change to a _clean + reliable_ portfolio if Calpine closes.**  
   With **FERC approval in hand** and DOJ review as the final gate, the **Calpine** acquisition creates a coast‑to‑coast platform (nuclear + gas + geothermal + retail) built to shape 24/7 supply for data centers. Management reiterated **Q4‑2025 closing** on last week’s call. citeturn9news20turn9search1turn9search3

3) **Operating momentum and visibility.**  
   Q3’25: CEG delivered **$3.04** adj. EPS and **narrowed FY25 guidance to $9.05–$9.45**—while reiterating that Calpine remains on track. That’s not “hype”; it’s cash‑flowing nuclear plus retail/hedges with upside when new PPAs and restarts convert. citeturn9search1turn9search9

4) **Valuation: premium, but more defensible than the other ‘AI‑power’ leaders.**  
   Snapshot today: **~32× forward P/E** and **~18–23× EV/EBITDA** (depending on source/forward window). That’s rich, but **still cheaper** than GE Vernova (GEV) on **~46× forward P/E** and far above‑market EV/EBITDA, and cheaper than Quanta (PWR) on **~35–37× forward P/E / ~25× EV/EBITDA**—both excellent businesses, both priced for perfection. citeturn9search0turn9search4turn9search6turn6search3turn11search4turn11search5

5) **Asymmetric optionality without tech risk.**  
   CEG’s core skill is contracting and operating baseload zero‑carbon. It doesn’t depend on winning the OEM race or flawless mega‑EPC execution. New 24/7 PPAs, nuclear **uprates**, and the TMI‑1 restart are all legible levers. citeturn4search6

---

## What could break it (and how to price that risk)

- **Regulatory/Deal risk:** DOJ could delay or condition **Calpine**. If the deal slips, near‑term multiple compression is possible; long‑term thesis (nuclear scarcity + 24/7 PPAs) still stands. Management continues to guide to a **Q4‑2025 close**. citeturn9search3  
- **Nuclear operations:** forced outages or restart slippage (e.g., TMI‑1) would push revenue right; the 20‑year PPA reduces merchant exposure but not execution requirements. citeturn4search2  
- **Market exposure:** even with hedges/retail, parts of the portfolio are tied to PJM and other markets; adding Calpine increases commodity/retail mix—part of the point is _flexibility_, but it adds some volatility. citeturn9news20

**Positioning note:** If I must own one name for the AI power decade, I’d **own CEG outright** and _add_ on any DOJ‑noise dip or on Calpine close/tangible 24/7 PPA wins. If you want a barbell later, pair with a cheaper “picks‑and‑shovels” grid name (e.g., **HUBB**) or the gas backbone (**WMB**)—but the single‑ticker choice is still CEG at today’s set‑up. citeturn8search3turn3finance3

---

## Why not the other top candidates (at _current_ prices)?

- **GE Vernova (GEV):** Phenomenal fundamentals (Q3 orders +55% organically; gas slot reservations **62 GW**; electrification backlog **~$26B**; buying the rest of **Prolec** transformers), but the stock carries **venture‑like multiples** after a massive run. Great business, stretched entry. citeturn4search0turn5search1turn4search12  
- **Quanta (PWR):** Best‑in‑class grid EPC with massive backlog—but trading **~35–37× forward P/E / ~25× EV/EBITDA**. Execution must be near‑flawless; I’d rather own it _on weakness_ than name it the single best buy _today_. citeturn11search4turn11search5  
- **Eaton (ETN):** A powerhouse for data‑center electrification (Q3 data‑center orders **~+70%**; acquiring **Boyd Thermal** for liquid cooling), but also on **mid‑30s P/E**/**~26–27× EV/EBITDA**—a lot already priced in. citeturn7search9turn7search0turn8search2  
- **Williams (WMB):** Excellent 10‑year compounder with Transco and **Southeast Supply Enhancement** (1.6 Bcf/d) and a new “power innovation” wedge; lower valuation but lower growth torque than CEG to the **clean** scarcity premium. citeturn6search8turn6search21

---

## What I’d watch next (to add or trim)
1) **Calpine close** and pro‑forma capital allocation. citeturn9search1  
2) **New 24/7 PPAs** with hyperscalers and visibility on **uprates/restarts** beyond TMI‑1. citeturn4search2  
3) **Q4/FY prints**: confirmation that EPS/FCF track to the high end of guidance as load tightness builds. citeturn9search1

---

### Headlines to skim
navlistCEG: recent developmentsturn9news20,turn9news21,turn4news41

If you want, I’ll translate this into a one‑pager (sizing, add/trim triggers, downside case) so you can act immediately.

supporting_websites.title: GE Vernova Stock Gets Buy Rating. Why Electricity Is 'Cool' Again.
supporting_websites.snippet: GE Vernova's stock saw a rise following a positive rating from Baird analyst Ben Kallo, who began coverage with a Buy rating and a price target of $448 per share. GE Vernova, which split from GE in April 2024, has a storied history in electricity generation. The increase in electric vehicles and AI data centers has reignited electricity demand in the U.S., positioning GE Vernova favorably in the market. Kallo highlighted the company's central role in energy and grid infrastructure, predicting margin expansion and enhanced pricing power. GE Vernova's stock increased 0.7%, closing at $370.31, while broader indexes also saw gains. Approximately 72% of analysts rate the stock as Buy, with an average target of $424. Kallo's target implies a 37x multiple on his 2026 EPS estimate of $11.98, reflecting optimism on the company's growth trajectory.

items.title: Constellation Energy to buy Calpine in blockbuster $16.4 billion U.S. power deal
items.snippet: Constellation Energy has agreed to purchase Calpine Corp for $16.4 billion, making this one of the largest transactions in the U.S. power industry. The acquisition involves cash and stock, bringing Calpine's total value, including debt, to $26.6 billion. This significant move comes amidst increasing electricity demand driven by energy-intensive AI data centers and the electrification of transportation and buildings. The deal will position Constellation as the largest independent power provider in the U.S., adding 60 gigawatts of capacity from low-emission sources like nuclear, natural gas, and geothermal. Constellation's CEO, Joe Dominguez, highlighted the unprecedented growth in product demand, and the deal is expected to enhance Constellation's free cash flow by $2 billion annually. Shares of Constellation surged in response to the news. The acquisition will also expand Constellation's presence in Texas and California, crucial markets for energy consumption, and increase its workforce by 20%. The transaction is anticipated to finalize in late 2025.
